Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: the role of fluids in intermediate-depth seismicity and wedge anisotropy: Case studies for Cascadia and Alaska, with a comparison to Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main goal of this study is to determine whether the presence of fluids within Earth's mantle is a controlling factor determining where earthquakes occur within subduction zones, specifically along the fault that enables the down-going tectonic plate to slip deeper into surrounding viscous mantle. The fact that this seismicity is located within the crust at 'cool' subduction zones, such as Alaska and Tohoku, versus in the mantle at 'warm' subduction zones, such as Cascadia and Nankai, suggests that fluids play an important role. Directional dependence of seismic wave propagation speeds will be assessed, so that possible bias in earthquake locations can be accounted for. Simultaneously, information about deformation within the viscously flowing mantle will be obtained. Ratios of shear and compressional wave velocities will suggest where fluids are present or not. These constraints will guide computer modeling of mantle flow and temperature in the subduction zones. These results will be linked to petrologic models of mineral phase change associated with plate dehydration that introduce fluids near the plate interface and lead to the generation of arc volcanism.

In-depth collaboration by three geoscientists- a geodynamist, petrologist, and seismologist, serves as a model of interdisciplinary Earth System research. Graduate and undergraduate students will receive training in the use of state-of-the-art methods in their sub-discipline as well as learning how to address interplay with evolving results from complementary sub disciplines. The international collaboration with Japanese scientists provides access to the best instrumented and well-studied Japanese subduction system. The study leverages ongoing work in the NSF GeoPRISMS and EarthScope Programs at Cascadia and that planned for Alaska.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over geologic time, water on the Earth’s surface is continually transported to its interior at subduction zone plate boundaries, some of which returns to the surface at arc volcanoes. As subducting plates descend into the earth, a series of metamorphic reactions release this water bound within minerals in subducting sediment, crust and mantle. The release of water triggers some of the planet’s deepest earthquakes, produces melting that leads to volcanos on the overlying arc, and forms new metamorphic rocks in the overlying material. This project aims to understand this long-term water cycle through an integration of numerical modeling, studies of metamorphic rocks at relevant conditions, and seismological observations of modern subduction zones. It addresses questions such as where the water release occurs, where and how that water might be stored or transported over geologic time, and the relationship between this water and earthquakes. In particular the project developed new high-resolution finite element models of the dynamics and thermal structure of subduction zones, using petrological and mineral physics constraints to guide the choices for material properties and to predict the seismological expression of these models. By modeling the propagation of seismic waves from earthquakes, the predictions are compared with observations to develop a suite of models that satisfy the observations and are physically self-consistent.

One byproduct of this project has been a new, easily usable set of software tools and databases for predicting the seismic wavespeeds of different rock types at high pressures and temperatures. This tool allows estimates for most major and many minor rock types expected in subduction zone conditions, to allow model predictions to be tested. These tools have been also heavily used in classrooms and labs around the country.

A major result has been a reassessment of the ability of the upper mantle in subduction zones to hold water, and the amount of water stored there. Although thermal models allow a water volume equivalent to several percent of the global ocean, we can show that the time required for such storage is way too long compared with ages of modern plate boundaries – with a couple of important exceptions. Limited seismic observations support this assessment. The result is that nearly water subducting must either come out in the volcanic arc or descend deeper into the mantle, where it resides a long time.

We also confirm that subduction zones are very cold in the region between the deep-sea trench and a couple of tens of km of the volcanic arc. This has been argued previously on the basis of surface heat flow measurements, which are limited to 3-4 subduction zones on earth, and on from the energy loss or attenuation of seismic waves that pass through these regions – a highly temperature-dependent process. However, the rock record indicates higher temperatures in samples metamorphosed at these depths. We show that the inconsistency of the rock record cannot be reconciled with multiple other observations, indicating that it is providing a biased sample of earth conditions. This effort provided a framework for comparing modeling methods by multiple groups.

Finally, we examine the amount of water entering trenches bound in minerals within subducting mantle, through some data from the Alaska subduction zone. We show that there are strong variations between segments of this subduction zone that correlate with abundance of deeper earthquakes, providing clear evidence that the release of this water produces deep earthquakes.
